title: 108_hr482
content:
The "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" and "State" and allows for the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. Tracts in Okaloosa County include various parcels such as A-942d, A-943, A-944, A-945, and A-959, with descriptions of their locations and sizes. Several tracts of land in Florida are available for sale or exchange, including parcels in Liberty County and Lake County. These tracts range from 0.5 acres to 127.2 acres and are described by their specific locations and sizes. Several tracts of land in Florida are available for sale or exchange, ranging from 0.5 acres to 127.2 acres. The parcels are located in Liberty County and Lake County, with detailed descriptions of their sizes and specific locations. Some examples include tract C-2209b in Lake County, consisting of approximately 39.41 acres, and tract C-2210 in Marion County, consisting of approximately 30 acres. The Secretary may modify land descriptions for sale or exchange based on surveys or public interest. Offers can be solicited for parcels ranging from 0.5 to 127.2 acres in Liberty County, Lake County, and Marion County. The Secretary has the authority to solicit offers for the sale or exchange of land, rejecting offers that are inadequate or not in the public interest. The land can be sold publicly or privately, with the option to use a real estate broker and pay them a standard commission. The Secretary of the Air Force must concur on the sale of certain parcels of land. The Secretary of the Air Force must approve the sale of specific land parcels. Cash equalization may be accepted if non-Federal land's value is lower in an exchange. Proceeds from sales or exchanges are deposited in the Sisk Act fund for the Secretary's discretionary use. The Sisk Act (Public Law 90-171) allows the Secretary to use deposited funds for acquiring land for the National Forest System and reimbursing costs related to land sales and exchanges, including real estate broker commissions. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION.

Land acquired by the United States under this Act shall be subject to the Weeks Act and administered according to laws applicable to the National Forest System. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws.
